Though he were stonayed þat stonde, he strikes ful sare; He gurdes to sir Gawayne, Thorghe ventaile and pesayne; He wanted no?te to be slayne Þe brede of ane hare. XLVI Hardely þene þes haþelese one helmes þey hewe, Þei betene downe beriles, and bourdures bright; Shildes one shildres, þat shene were to shewe, Fretted were in fyne golde, þei failene in fighte; Stones of Iral þey strenkel and strewe, Stiþe stapeles of stele þey strike done sti?te; Burnes bannene þe tyme þe bargane was brewe, The dougheti withe dyntes so delfully were dight. Thene gretes Gaynour, with bothe here gray ene, For þo dou?eti þat fi?te, Were manly mached of mighte, Withe oute resone or righte, As al mene sene. XLVII Thus gretis Gaynour, withe boþe here gray yene, For gref of sir Gawayne, grisly was wounded; The knighte of corage was cruel and kene, And withe a stele bronde þat sturne oft stonded; Al þe cost of kny?t he carf downe clene, Þorghe þe riche mailes, þat ronke were and rounde. With a teneful touche he ta?t him in tene; He gurdes sir Galerone groueling on gronde. Grisly one gronde he groned one grene; Als wounded as he was, Sone buredely he ras, And folowed fast one his tras, With a swerde kene. XLVIII Kenely þat cruel keuered one hi?te, And withe a scas of care in cautil he strikes, And waynes at sir Wawyne, þat worþely wighte; But him lymped þe worse, and þat me wel likes. He atteled withe a slenke haf slayne him in sli?te; Þe swerd swapped one his swange, and one þe mayle slikes, And Gawayne bi þe coler keppes þe kni?te. Þene his lemmane one loft skrilles and skrikes; Ho gretes one Gaynour, with gronyng grylle; “Lady makeles of mighte, Haf mercy one yondre kni?te, That is so delfulle di?te, If hit be thi wille.” XLIX Wisly dame Waynour to þe king wente, Ho cau?te of her coronalle, and kneled him tille: “As þou art ioy roiall, richest of rente, And I þi wife, wedded at þi owne wille, Þes burnes in þe bataile so blede on þe bente, They arne wery, I wis, and wonded fulle ille; Þorghe here shene sheldes here shuldres are shent; The grones of sir Gawayne dos my hert grille. The grones of sir Gawayne greuene me sare; Woldest þou, leve lorde, Make þes knightes accorde, Hit were a grete conforde For alle þat þere ware.” L Thene spak sir Galerone to Gawayne þe good: “I wende neuer wee in þis world had bene half so wi?te; Here I make þe releyse, renke, by þe rode, And by rial reysone relese þe my righte; And siþene make the monradene, with a mylde mode, As mane of medlert makeles of mighte.” He talkes touard þe king one hie þer he stode, And bede þat burly his bronde, þat burneshed was bri?te. “Of rentes and richesse I make þe releyse.” Downe kneled þe kni?te, And carped wordes one hi?te; The king stode vp righte And commaunded pes. LI The king commaunded pes, and cried one hi?te, And Gawayne was goodly, and laft for his sake. Þene lordes to listes þey lopen ful li?te, Sir Ewayne fi? Griane, and Arrak fi? lake, Sir Drurelat and Moylard, þat most were of mi?te. Boþe þes trauayled mene þey truly vp take; Vnnethe mi?te þo sturne stonde vp ri?te; What for buffetes and blode, here blees wex blake; Here blees were brosed, for beting of brondes. Withe outene more lettynge, Di?te was here sa?tlynge; Bifore þe comly kinge, Þei held vp here hondes. LII “Here I gif sir Gawayne, with gersone and golde, Al þe Glamergane londe, with greues so grene; Þe worship of Wales, at wil and al wolde, Withe Criffones Castelles, curnelled ful clene; Eke Vlstur halle, to hafe and to holde, Wayford and Waterforde in Wales, I wene; Two baronrees in Bretayne, with burghes so bolde, Þat arne batailed abou?te, and bigged ful bene. I shal di?te þe a Duke, and dubbe þe with honde, Withe þi þou sa?til with þe kni?te, Þat is so hardi and wi?te, And relese him his ri?te, And graunte him his londe.” LIII “Here I gif sir Galerone,” quod G[awayne], “with outen any gile, Al þe londes and þe lithes, fro lauer to layre, Connoke and carlele, Conyngham and Kile, Yet if he of cheualry chalange ham [?] for aire; Þe loþer, þe lemmoke, þe loynak, þe lile, Withe frethis and forestes, and fosses so faire; Vnder your lordeship to lenge here a while, And to þe rounde table to make repaire. I shall refeff him in felde, in forestes so faire.” Boþe þe king and þe quene, And al þe dou?ti by-dene, Þorghe þe greues so grene, Carlele þei caire. LIV The king to Carlele is comene, with kni?tes so kene, And al þe rounde table one rial aray. Þe wees, þat werene wounded so woþely, I wene, Surgenes sone saued, soþely to say; Bothe confortes þe knightes, þe king and þe quene; Thei were dubbed Dukes, bothe one a day. There he wedded his wife, wlonkest, I wene, Withe giftes and garsons, sir Galerone þe gay. Þus þat haþel in hi? with holdes þat hende; Whane he was saued sonde, Þei made sir Galerone þat stonde A kni?te of þe table ronde, To his lyues ende. LV Waynour gared wisely write in þe west, To al þe religious to rede and to singe; Prestes with processione to pray were prest, With a mylione of masses to make þe mynnynge. Boke lered mene, bisshops þe best, Þorghe al Bretayne besely þe burde gared rynge. Þis ferely bifelle in englond forest, Vnder a holte so hore at a huntyng; Suche a huntyng in haast is no?te to be hide. Thus to forest þey fore, Þes sterne knightes in store; In þe tyme of Arthore, This anter be-tide.
